data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e460fea/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe9%2F91%2Ffd9210c64c819a5cc5abf1d41704%2Fsteinberg-04xx24-12.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Venezuelan musicians are members of some of the world’s best orchestras, from the Berlin Philharmonic to our own Chicago Symphony.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>When she worked for El Sistema during the Chávez years, Núñez-Ruch notes that many within the organization were clear-eyed about Venezuela’s political realities. At the same time, El Sistema receives some 80% of its funding from the Venezuelan government, leaving the organization essentially stuck.</p><p>“In my perception, [the attitude of El Sistema] was, ‘Say whatever you want to say as long as we can sustain the work.’ That's part of the political strategy of the organization and its leadership,” she says.</p><p>The Venezuelan government’s dysfunction and strong-arming tendencies sometimes snowball into El Sistema itself. While living in Chicago in the early 2000s, Lorenz was helping spearhead a community program with the Chicago Symphony in Pilsen. Abreu pushed Lorenz to forge a connection between the CSO and El Sistema, which never materialized.</p><p>But Abreu, who was always “supportive” of Lorenz’s career, later reached out asking if Lorenz would be interested in returning to Venezuela. While Lorenz mulled the offer, Chávez named the composer to replace the current president of the Instituto Universitario De Estudios Musicales in Caracas via his weekly television program, “Aló Presidente.” Lorenz was shocked. He’d only been in early talks for the position, which he quickly declined. The episode effectively ended his relationship with Abreu. “He was very disappointed after that,” Lorenz recalls. (Abreu died in 2018.)</p><p>More recently, British scholar Geoffrey Baker has cast doubt on the idea that the program prioritizes social uplift at all. In the absence of demographic data, which El Sistema keeps private, his 2014 book “El Sistema: Orchestrating Venezuela's Youth”<i> </i>leaned on hundreds of interviews and a year observing El Sistema’s <i>núcleos</i>. Baker’s findings indicated that the program served a core demographic of middle-to-upper-class children, with impoverished students in the minority.</p><p>Additionally, Baker observed that El Sistema’s “revolutionary” educational philosophy was, if anything, retrograde. <i>Núcleos</i> more often resembled old-school European conservatoires where endless hours of practice were the norm.</p><p>“I naively thought that when Abreu died and more musicians left the country, some would start speaking out about the problems,” Baker wrote to WBEZ via e-mail. “But I hadn't counted on the fact that El Sistema's good name was essential to their job prospects overseas — it was their meal ticket.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-af0000" name="image-af0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/04d6664/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2Fde%2Fb722f4614163949410d8b02d0d2e%2Ficeprotest-260111-028.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/9d80562/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2Fde%2Fb722f4614163949410d8b02d0d2e%2Ficeprotest-260111-028.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bad3ba9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2Fde%2Fb722f4614163949410d8b02d0d2e%2Ficeprotest-260111-028.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Protesters gather in Water Tower Park downtown to denounce the arrest of Venezuela’s President Maduro and the ICE-involved killings of Renee Nicole Good and Silverio Villegas González as part of a national day of action, Saturday, Jan. 10, 2026." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bad3ba9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2Fde%2Fb722f4614163949410d8b02d0d2e%2Ficeprotest-260111-028.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e0fe5f0/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2Fde%2Fb722f4614163949410d8b02d0d2e%2Ficeprotest-260111-028.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bad3ba9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2Fde%2Fb722f4614163949410d8b02d0d2e%2Ficeprotest-260111-028.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Protesters gather in Water Tower Park in Downtown Chicago in January 2026 to denounce the arrest of Venezuela’s President Maduro. The flashpoint year in U.S.-Venezuelan relations has disrupted a pipeline of musicians from the country to orchestral programs all over the world.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Núñez-Ruch doesn’t dispute accounts of internal politicking and interminable rehearsals. But she does feel as though El Sistema was operating with more political deftness than it is often given credit for. She points to El Sistema’s use of broadly Venezuelan symbolism on its tours rather than the United Socialist Party’s logo, at a time when that imagery was ubiquitous inside Venezuela.</p><p>“Managing that is not a small feat,” Núñez-Ruch said of the organization’s ability to detach itself from Chávez-related iconography. “It’s something that is very herculean, and only in hindsight, and outside of the country, can I see how masterful it was not to cross that line.”</p><p>Lorenz likewise “owes a debt of gratitude” to El Sistema, he wrote via e-mail, despite his own mixed feelings. Next month, Dudamel will conduct a <a class="Link" href="https://www.laphil.com/musicdb/pieces/7415/humboldts-nature" target="_blank" ><u>new work</u></a> of Lorenz’s to commemorate his final season with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, which he has led since 2009. The piece is inspired by Venezuela’s landscape: the rugged eastern coast, birds twittering in the six-mile-long Guácharo Cave, and drumbeats ringing over Lake Tacarigua, to the north.</p><p>“The sad part of all these things that have happened in the past month is that it’s trying to bring us back 100 years, where the only thing that Venezuela has is oil,” Lorenz says. “I thought we were beyond that.”</p>
entries.author: Hannah Edgar | WBEZ

entries.title: Why did the FBI recruit Catholic high school girls in Chicago?
entries.summary: <p>One day in 1947, FBI officials showed up at Notre Dame High School for Girls on Chicago’s Northwest Side. They were looking for a few good Catholic girls — to work at the FBI. One of the students at the school that day, Patricia DePasquale, talked years later about these FBI recruiters.</p><p>“Working for the FBI, getting this job after high school, it gave her the independence and freedom that I think she wanted,” said DePasquale’s daughter Carmie Callobre.</p><p>Callobre, who lives in Skokie, said that back in the 1940s, her mother jumped at the opportunity to work for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. For the next several years, DePasquale was a switchboard operator for the FBI’s Chicago office.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-d10000" name="image-d10000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ff32c2f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1912x1073+0+819/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F55%2F02%2F466387df48c492f05a66c2bb0f11%2Funnamed-2.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a793549/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1912x1073+0+819/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F55%2F02%2F466387df48c492f05a66c2bb0f11%2Funnamed-2.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/72e7942/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1912x1073+0+819/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F55%2F02%2F466387df48c492f05a66c2bb0f11%2Funnamed-2.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Patricia DePasquale" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/72e7942/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1912x1073+0+819/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F55%2F02%2F466387df48c492f05a66c2bb0f11%2Funnamed-2.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4dcdacf/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1912x1073+0+819/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F55%2F02%2F466387df48c492f05a66c2bb0f11%2Funnamed-2.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/72e7942/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1912x1073+0+819/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F55%2F02%2F466387df48c492f05a66c2bb0f11%2Funnamed-2.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Patricia DePasquale was a student at Notre Dame High School for Girls when the FBI hired her to work as a switchboard operator in 1947.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Courtesy of Carmie Callobre</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>She even dated some FBI agents. “Mom was gorgeous when she was young, and she dated a lot of people,” Callobre said. “And she definitely did date FBI agents. They would just take her anywhere downtown. She would go to, probably, the Berghoff. Definitely Italian Village.”</p><p>DePasquale eventually left the FBI and started working at a law firm. The man she eventually fell in love with and married — Callobre’s father, Edmund Daugird — was the manager of a bar in Rosemont. DePasquale, who died in 2024, later worked at restaurants, catering businesses and a corporate cafeteria. Years later, Callobre wondered how common it was for the FBI to recruit girls from Catholic schools in Chicago.</p><p>“I was flabbergasted the first time … she told us about that,” Callobre said. “I thought, ‘Well, that’s odd.’”</p><p>In more recent decades, the FBI has become known for its competitive hiring process. But there is an extensive history of the agency recruiting high school girls to work office jobs in an earlier era. How much of that initiative focused on Chicago and Catholic schools? The FBI did not answer requests for information for this story, but historians and former high school recruits cast light on those hiring practices, which eventually set the stage for women to become FBI special agents.</p><h3><b> ‘Catholic girls would fit in’ at the FBI</b></h3><p>Even as Pat DePasquale’s life diverged from the FBI, she kept in touch with her former co-workers at the bureau, maintaining those ties by joining the <a class="Link" href="https://thefbialumni.com/" target="_blank" ><u>Society of FBI Alumni</u></a>.</p><p>“It started as a group of ladies who went to lunch and just wanted to keep their FBI connection and their friendships together,” said Western Springs resident Jane McCarty, who was the Society of FBI Alumni’s president until November.</p><p>Formally organized in 1973, the alumni group began inviting men to join in 1979, but most of the members are still women. “We have agents in our group, but predominantly we’re support staff — intelligence analysts, IT people, typists, the clerical staff,” McCarty said. The national organization has a chapter in Chicago with 120 members.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-a80000" name="image-a80000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/763f7b7/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5599x3142+0+667/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F2c%2F0f%2F135917634cb6892af148429a0c3d%2F1948studentsfrontdoors.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f9a67da/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5599x3142+0+667/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F2c%2F0f%2F135917634cb6892af148429a0c3d%2F1948studentsfrontdoors.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7ebd23e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5599x3142+0+667/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F2c%2F0f%2F135917634cb6892af148429a0c3d%2F1948studentsfrontdoors.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="1948StudentsFrontDoors.jpg" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7ebd23e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5599x3142+0+667/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F2c%2F0f%2F135917634cb6892af148429a0c3d%2F1948studentsfrontdoors.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4cfc751/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5599x3142+0+667/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F2c%2F0f%2F135917634cb6892af148429a0c3d%2F1948studentsfrontdoors.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7ebd23e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5599x3142+0+667/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F2c%2F0f%2F135917634cb6892af148429a0c3d%2F1948studentsfrontdoors.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Students stand at the door of Notre Dame High School for Girls in Chicago, Illinois in 1948.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p><i>SNDdeN Virtual Archives</i></p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>McCarty said the FBI regularly sent recruiters to high schools all over the country, and not just Catholic schools. Even now, the FBI has <a class="Link" href="https://www.fbi.gov/how-we-can-help-you/outreach" target="_blank" ><u>Teen Academy and Youth Academy programs</u></a>, which “allow high school and middle school students an opportunity to get a comprehensive look into today’s FBI.”</p><p>When McCarty was a student at a public high school in California in 1968, FBI recruiters showed up there. A month after McCarty graduated, she started working for the FBI as a stenographer.</p><p>“Today, I probably could not get my job, because you need a college degree,” she said.</p><p>This recruiting tactic was not targeted at Catholic school girls exclusively. But when McCarty transferred to the FBI’s Chicago office in 1979, she did notice a number of the local employees were from Notre Dame High School for Girls. (Located at 3000 N. Mango Ave. in the Belmont Central neighborhood, the school closed in 2016.)</p><p>“Those Catholic girls would fit in because, you know, you had to have a certain-length skirt,” McCarty said. “The rules were the rules. I mean, we couldn’t wear pants until ’72. There were so many rules like that, it would be like a Catholic school.”</p><p>Rhodri Jeffreys-Jones, author of the 2007 book <a class="Link" href="https://yalebooks.yale.edu/book/9780300142846/the-fbi/" target="_blank" ><i><u>The FBI: A History</u></i></a>, said a strategy of hiring Catholic girls would line up perfectly with longtime FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover’s attitude in the post-World War II years, when the United States was in the grip of fears over communism.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-floatRight> <div class="Enhancement-item" 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8672315/2147483647/strip/true/crop/435x244+0+198/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F63%2F85%2Fa67ed36b4f6a94d9b11637b6c210%2Fservice-pnp-ppmsca-86100-86153r.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d14d103/2147483647/strip/true/crop/435x244+0+198/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F63%2F85%2Fa67ed36b4f6a94d9b11637b6c210%2Fservice-pnp-ppmsca-86100-86153r.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Women FBI employees working in an office in 1976.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, U.S. News & World Report Magazine Collection, [<b> </b>LC-DIG-ppmsca-86153]</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“He placed a huge emphasis on recruiting Catholics because he thought that Catholics would be reliably anti-communist,” said Jeffreys-Jones, a professor of American history at the University of Edinburgh in Scotland. “They had the moral code and backbone. He went out of his way to praise the Catholic schools in America. He explicitly said that these schools have amongst their teaching staff not a single example of an atheist. And of course, communism, amongst other things, stands for atheism. That was his outlook.”</p><p>Hoover did send FBI agents to recruit young women from Catholic schools on the East Coast; Jeffreys-Jones said he’d be surprised if Hoover didn’t do the same thing in Chicago, a city still heavily influenced by its Catholic culture.</p><p>During World War II, the FBI had vastly expanded the number of women on its payroll. In addition to working as secretaries, stenographers and switchboard operators, women began to take on more skilled activities, such as statistical analysis and code-breaking. “However, they still weren’t permitted to become the elite special agents,” Jeffreys-Jones said.</p><p>Hoover’s sexism was a major obstacle to that sort of reform, although as Jeffreys-Jones noted, women faced similar prejudice throughout the world of law enforcement. “I think it is frustrating for women to serve only in the lower ranks of an agency like the FBI, and we do have proof definitive that women can make very good detectives,” he said. (As evidence, Jeffreys-Jones pointed to 19th-century Chicago sleuth Kate Warne, whom he wrote about in his 2025 book<a class="Link" href="https://press.georgetown.edu/Book/Allan-Pinkerton" target="_blank" ><u> </u><i><u>Allan Pinkerton: America’s Legendary Detective and the Birth of Private Security</u></i></a><i>.</i>)</p><h3><b>Moving up the ranks</b></h3><p>In 1971, 16-year-old Nancy McRae wrote a letter to Hoover saying she hoped to become a special agent. Hoover wrote back: “Because of the nature of the duties our Special Agents are called upon to perform, we do not employ women in that position. We must have Agents who are qualified to cope with any situation they may face.”</p><p>Hoover died in 1972, ending his 48-year reign as the director of the FBI and its precursor agency, the Bureau of Investigation. Just two months after his death, the FBI finally allowed women to become special agents.</p><p>“What I know, what all of you know, and what Hoover either did not know or did not acknowledge, is that women are absolutely essential to effective law enforcement,” then-FBI Director Christopher Wray said in a <a class="Link" href="https://www.fbi.gov/news/speeches-and-testimony/director-wrays-remarks-at-the-women-in-federal-law-enforcement-annual-leadership-training" target="_blank" ><u>2024 speech</u></a> to the group Women in Federal Law Enforcement. At the time he spoke, 24% of FBI special agents — and 37% of agent trainees — were women.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-a20000" name="image-a20000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/21c03f8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+211/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F63%2F65%2F8e06fa3c4f2d90b3230262ff6383%2Ffbi-111319.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a7ef6b5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+211/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F63%2F65%2F8e06fa3c4f2d90b3230262ff6383%2Ffbi-111319.JPG data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/daefcd8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+211/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F63%2F65%2F8e06fa3c4f2d90b3230262ff6383%2Ffbi-111319.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="FBI-111319" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/daefcd8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+211/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F63%2F65%2F8e06fa3c4f2d90b3230262ff6383%2Ffbi-111319.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d13c39c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+211/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F63%2F65%2F8e06fa3c4f2d90b3230262ff6383%2Ffbi-111319.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/daefcd8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+211/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F63%2F65%2F8e06fa3c4f2d90b3230262ff6383%2Ffbi-111319.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>The Seal of the FBI at the Chicago office of the FBI in 2019. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>James Foster/Chicago Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Wray resigned in January 2025 as Donald Trump returned to the presidency, setting the stage for Trump to appoint Kash Patel as FBI director. Since then, the word “Diversity” was painted over on a wall at the FBI Academy, and <a class="Link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2026/01/22/magazine/trump-kash-patel-fbi-agents.html?unlocked_article_code=1.MlA.NP6B.MFOP95LdVLW9&smid=url-share" target="_blank" ><u>critics said</u></a> proposed changes to the FBI’s physical fitness standards would be unfair to women.</p><p>Christina Riebandt, an FBI special agent in Chicago, wrote a <a class="Link" href="https://jerriwilliams.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/Nancy-McRae-Story_December-2021.pdf" target="_blank" ><u>2021 article</u></a> for the FBI’s internal magazine, The Investigator, about Nancy McRae, who’d received that rejection letter from Hoover back in 1971. “Many women in the Bureau, myself included, have this letter pinned up or framed at our desks as a reminder that we once were unable to hold the position we have now,” Riebandt wrote.</p><p>McRae, who was born in Chicago and raised in Connecticut, did end up working in law enforcement after all, but at the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration rather than the FBI. McRae said she felt “honored” that Hoover’s letter to her became a touchstone for women in the FBI. “To think that a letter that made me so angry 50 years ago could bring such joy and happiness today is truly amazing,” McRae told Riebandt.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-040000" name="image-040000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b92fc62/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3024x1697+0+154/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fbb%2F5e%2F3d7fcc154cb2a8d5f61ae37d6a3b%2Fdirkson-federal-building.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Then-FBI Chicago Chief Kathleen McChesney at a press conference in 2000.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Jean Lachat/Chicago Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Notable women in the FBI have included <a class="Link" href="https://www.fbi.gov/video-repository/km-women-agents-2012.mp4/view" target="_blank" ><u>Kathleen McChesney</u></a>. She’d also been rebuffed by the FBI back in 1971, when she was a student at Washington State University. An FBI recruiter on campus <a class="Link" href="https://magazine.wsu.edu/2013/07/31/kathleen-mcchesney-71-agent-of-change/" target="_blank" ><u>refused to give her</u></a> a job application, saying, “The FBI doesn’t have women as agents.” Hired after Hoover’s death, McChesney eventually became the special agent in charge of the Chicago division in the early 2000s, overseeing investigations of Cicero Town President Betty Loren-Maltese and Gov. George Ryan.</p><p>Although Jane McCarty began working for the FBI during Hoover’s reign, she said she didn’t experience much discrimination. She eventually worked her way up through the ranks to become an asset forfeiture investigator. “Somebody took a chance on me,” she said. “Somebody said, ‘I think she could do the job.’”</p><p>Callobre said her mom spoke nostalgically of her time as an FBI employee — and McCarty said that attitude is common among the Society of FBI Alumni’s members.</p><p>“We still have the FBI in our heart,” McCarty said. “We all have very fond memories of our work there, and are very proud.”</p><p><i>Robert Loerzel is a journalist based in Chicago.</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" class="Figure-content"><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Courtesy of Carmie Callobre</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div>After growing up on Chicago’s Northwest Side and in Niles, Carmie Callobre studied theology at Loyola University. Now a longtime Skokie resident, she worked as an administrative assistant at various businesses before retiring in 2013.<br><br>Over the next dozen years, she often visited her mother, whose married name at the end of her life was Pat Daugird-Ehlen.<br><br>“She had short-term memory loss, but she was doing OK,” Carmie said, noting that her mom was known for her sense of humor. She recalled a doctor visiting her mom in early 2024: “He said, ‘Do you know what day it is?’ And she said, ‘It’s my birthday.’ He said, ‘Do you know how old you are?’ And she said, ‘I was born in 1929. You do the math.’”<br><br>Although Carmie had countless conversations with her mom, she said her mom never did tell her very much about what it was like working for the FBI. That was one topic about which she was “very tight-lipped.”<br></div> </div><p></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-750000" name="html-embed-module-750000"></a><script async src="https://modules.wearehearken.com/wbez/embed/4190.js"></script> </div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Robert Loerzel

entries.title: Lights, camera, Jackson: Civil Rights leader also became a pop culture presence
entries.summary: <p>It was 1971, and the world still seemed new. </p><p>It was especially true if you were a 6-year-old, plopped in front of a black-and-white Zenith TV, waiting for the latest episode of "Sesame Street" — a program that had debuted just a couple seasons earlier — to air on WTTW.</p><p>At some point during the show, between the quick-hit lessons about letters and numbers, the Rev. Jesse Jackson appears with a large group of young children, representing virtually every color and ethnic group.</p><p>With his Afro in full bloom, Jackson takes his youthful rainbow coalition through a call-and-response recitation of the Rev. William Borders poem that Jackson made internationally known: "I Am Somebody."</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" data-embed> <iframe width="200" height="150" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/zuZV7ES4VE8?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen title="Jesse Jackson 'I Am Somebody' on Sesame Street"></iframe> </div> </div></div><p>PBS, which broadcast "Sesame Street," was still in its infancy. The landmark Civil Rights Act of 1964 was as recent then as, say, the COVID-19 crisis is now. And 30-year-old Jackson was at the start of a quarter-century run as a cultural presence.</p><p>Jackson's decades civil rights efforts and running for president in 1984 and 1988 are his most important and lasting work. But that he did this while also forging a position in the nation's pop cultural firmament is nonetheless remarkable.</p><p>He could be inspirational, as he was on "Sesame Street" and during a 1989 appearance on the sitcom <a class="Link" href="https://youtu.be/KUDQhdKxjH8?si=xCHW2WvVfPZTz8b0" target="_blank" >“A Different World,”</a> talking about the role of young people in elections.</p><p>But Jackson could also be quite funny, as evidenced by the straight-faced delivery of Dr. Suess' "Green Eggs and Ham" on Saturday Night Live in 1991.</p><p>"He understood media," Charles Whitaker, dean of Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism. said. "He understood the relevance of being able to engage with audiences. The combination of politician and preacher just made him a magnetic force."</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" data-embed> <iframe width="200" height="113" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/A1mqg4C0awA?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen title="Green Eggs and Ham narrated by the Reverend Jesse Jackson"></iframe> </div> </div></div><p></p><h3>Behind the camera</h3><p>Linking Black entertainers to the civil/political/economics rights movement was also important to Jackson. He was a producer of Wattstax, the 1972 benefit concert by Stax Records to mark the seventh anniversary of the Watts riots in Los Angeles. The event became a double album and a concert film in 1973.</p><p>Isaac Hayes, the Staple Singers, the Emotions, the Bar-Kays and comedian Richard Pryor were among the performers who got-down at Wattstax. But so did Jackson.</p><p>"This is a beautiful day," Jackson told the LA Memorial Coliseum audience in his opening speech. "It is a new day. It is a day of Black awareness. It is a day of Black people taking care of Black people’s business. We are together, we are unified and all in accord. Because when we are together we got power. And we can make decisions."</p><p>Later in 1972 at the International Amphitheatre at 42nd and Halsted streets, Jackson pulled off a similar effort: Save the Children, a benefit concert for his Operation PUSH. </p><p>The line up included Marvin Gaye, the Jackson Five, the Temptations, Roberta Flack, Curtis Mayfield, Bill Withers and more.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-4b0000" name="image-4b0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0367f7d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3840x2155+0+2/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fcb%2F3f%2Ff0a1bd474f98a2f0ac825b340ab0%2Fjackson5-1-1-47.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7b35a2e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3840x2155+0+2/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fcb%2F3f%2Ff0a1bd474f98a2f0ac825b340ab0%2Fjackson5-1-1-47.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/353d38e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3840x2155+0+2/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fcb%2F3f%2Ff0a1bd474f98a2f0ac825b340ab0%2Fjackson5-1-1-47.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="The Jackson 5 perform during the 1972 Black Expo in Chicago." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/353d38e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3840x2155+0+2/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fcb%2F3f%2Ff0a1bd474f98a2f0ac825b340ab0%2Fjackson5-1-1-47.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/27020ba/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3840x2155+0+2/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fcb%2F3f%2Ff0a1bd474f98a2f0ac825b340ab0%2Fjackson5-1-1-47.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/353d38e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3840x2155+0+2/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fcb%2F3f%2Ff0a1bd474f98a2f0ac825b340ab0%2Fjackson5-1-1-47.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>The Jackson 5 perform during the 1972 Black Expo in Chicago.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Courtesy of Save the Children</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>The homegrown Chi-Lites performed, too. The group was hot, having just scored with hits such as "Have You Seen Her?" and "Oh, Girl."</p><p>"People were wrapped around the block every day of that show," Marshall Thompson, the last surviving member of the original Chi-Lites said. He had been friends with Jackson since the 1960s. "I mean, it was like magic."</p><p>Thompson said Jackson encouraged the group to write their 1971 message song, "(For God's Sake) Give More Power to the People." The lyrics almost read like an excerpt of Jackson's speeches:</p><p>If you don't have enough to eat<br>How can you think of love?<br>You don't have the time to care<br>So it's crime you're guilty of</p><p>The Save the Children benefit was turned into a concert film that had a short theatrical run then went unseen for 50 years. Directed by Stan Lathan — a director of "Sesame Street" episodes during Jackson's 1971 appearance — the film was digitally restored and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/movies-and-tv/2024/10/18/save-the-children-chicago-jesse-jackson-stan-lathan-1972-black-expo-sammy-davis-jr" target="_blank" >put back in circulation</a> in 2024. </p><h3>Who’s got next?</h3><p>During his time in the cultural spotlight, Jackson was also parodied by Eddie Murphy on SNL and Keenan Ivory Wayans on the '90s FOX sketch show "In Living Color." </p><p>He hosted SNL in 1984. He made political points in his opening monologue — and snuck some wisecracks.</p><p>"I took [Fidel] Castro to church for the first time in 30 years," he said. "If I coulda stayed [in Cuba] longer, I coulda actually got him a shave."</p><p>"Being able to make fun of himself, I think made him more human," Jazz Institute of Chicago Executive Director Heather Ireland Robinson, who knows the Jackson family, said.</p><p>In 1990, Kris Kristofferson wrote a song called "Jesse Jackson" and sang it with Willie Nelson. The pair sang: "Hold on brother, Jesse Jackson. There's a better world a'coming. Where a man can hope a man will show some heart. You just keep right on believing. In the better side of human. They ain't ready for it yet, but it's a start. And you move'em when you hit'em in the heart."</p><p>Today's cultural and media landscape is as fragmented as it is ever-present. Can a civil rights leader today have the same impact as did Jackson? Likely not, Whitaker said.</p><p>"We don't see anyone breaking through quite like in the way that Jesse Jackson did," he said. "Even a Barack Obama, who's a phenomenon and a wonder in his own right, has not used that platform in the same way as Jesse Jackson."</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2026/02/17/rev-jesse-jackson-civil-rights-leader-rainbow-push-obituary" >Rev. Jesse Jackson, civil rights leader and Chicago icon, dead at 84</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>
entries.author: Lee Bey

entries.title: Is Chicago's food hall era over?
entries.summary: <h3>Good morning, Chicago. ✶</h3><p>🔎 <b>Below</b>: Despite the abrupt closure of Time Out Market, there's still hope for the food hall concept in Chicago.</p><p>🗞️ <b>Plus</b>: Chicagoans mourn Rev. Jesse Jackson, a list of the GOP candidates vying for Gov. JB Pritzker's seat and more news you need to know.</p><p>📧 <b>Subscribe</b>: <a class="Link" href="https://newsletter-hub.suntimes.com/" target="_blank" >Get this newsletter delivered to your inbox weekday mornings.</a></p><p>⏱️: <i>An 8-minute read</i></p><hr><p></p><h4>TODAY’S WEATHER 🌤️</h4><p>Partly sunny with a high near 65.</p><hr><p></p><h4>TODAY’S TOP STORY 🔎</h4><div class="Enhancement" alt="People eat at Sterling Food Hall in the Loop, Wednesday, Feb. 11, 2026. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/df40379/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6f%2Fe3%2F0b201be149f1b68621e00bd0a025%2Ffoodhallsurvival-260213-14.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/269255a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6f%2Fe3%2F0b201be149f1b68621e00bd0a025%2Ffoodhallsurvival-260213-14.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/df40379/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6f%2Fe3%2F0b201be149f1b68621e00bd0a025%2Ffoodhallsurvival-260213-14.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>People dined recently at Sterling Food Hall in the Loop.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-t/" target="_blank" >Despite Time Out Market’s abrupt closure, Chicago’s food hall era may not be over</a></h3><p></p><h5>Reporting by <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-i/" target="_blank" >Maggie Hennessy</a></h5><p><b>Food hall heydey</b>: More than a decade ago, food halls — the younger siblings of the chain-heavy suburban food court — roared onto the Chicago food scene as part of a national trend, touting local and chef-driven vendors and artisans. They allow a food-minded public to restaurant-shop — and for restaurateurs, they're a lower-risk entry point to test if a concept has legs.</p><p><b>Pandemic impact</b>: Many in the food industry point to COVID-19. When Time Out Market in Fulton Market closed last month, owners cited the pandemic's impact on office occupancy due to more people working from home. Time Out's vendors reportedly also noted its lack of investment in drawing customers.</p><p><b>Benefits remain</b>: Downtown foot traffic and <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-d/" target="_blank" >office tenancy</a> are reportedly creeping back up, and workers want compelling, wallet-friendly lunch options. Such spaces also remain incubators for promising concepts. And they are getting more savvy about marketing themselves to tourists, who appreciate local options close to the sights without the hassle of booking tables.</p><p><b>Still serving</b>: If you're looking to indulge in the concept, among the city's food halls still going strong are Sterling Food Hall, 125 S Clark St.; From Here On Food Hall in Market, 433 W Van Buren St.; and 88 Marketplace, 2105 S. Jefferson St.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-h/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4> REMEMBERING REV. JESSE JACKSON ✶</h4><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-b00000" name="image-b00000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d61b957/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2F53%2F0ba5b173438c9815cf0fcff65720%2Fjacksonlocalreact-260218-04.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/9e66362/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2F53%2F0ba5b173438c9815cf0fcff65720%2Fjacksonlocalreact-260218-04.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/485b4d9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2F53%2F0ba5b173438c9815cf0fcff65720%2Fjacksonlocalreact-260218-04.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="A mourner places flowers at a memorial for Rev. Jesse Jackson outside of Rainbow PUSH Coalition Headquarters in Kenwood, Tuesday, Feb. 17, 2026. Rev. Jackson passed away at the age of 84. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/485b4d9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2F53%2F0ba5b173438c9815cf0fcff65720%2Fjacksonlocalreact-260218-04.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/887e7cd/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2F53%2F0ba5b173438c9815cf0fcff65720%2Fjacksonlocalreact-260218-04.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/485b4d9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2F53%2F0ba5b173438c9815cf0fcff65720%2Fjacksonlocalreact-260218-04.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>A mourner places flowers at a memorial Tuesday for the Rev. Jesse Jackson outside Rainbow PUSH Coalition headquarters in Kenwood.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-k/" target="_blank" >Chicagoans mourn Rev. Jesse Jackson: ‘He had enough heart to challenge wrong’</a></h3><h3></h3><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-u/" target="_blank" >Mohammad Samra</a>, <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-o/" target="_blank" >Cindy Hernandez</a>, <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-b/" target="_blank" >Violet Miller</a>, <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-n/" target="_blank" >Elleiana Green</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-p/" target="_blank" >Mary Norkol</a></h5><p><b>Flowers for Jackson</b>: Many Chicagoans mourned Tuesday, struck by the death of civil rights icon the Rev. Jesse Jackson, 84. Flowers, a white balloon and a note to the Jackson family rested Tuesday morning on the pavement near the headquarters of the Rainbow PUSH Coalition, the nonprofit Jackson formed in 1970 that has spent decades working toward racial equality.</p><p><b>His legacy</b>: The Sun-Times and WBEZ spoke with community members, former colleagues, supporters, activists and Jackson's neighbors, who all reflected on their memories of the civil rights leader and the impact he made. Regarded as Martin Luther King Jr.'s protege, Jackson worked throughout the Civil Rights movement and after to champion rights for Black people. In the 1980s, Jackson ran the first viable presidential campaign by a Black candidate in the U.S.</p><p><b>Key quote</b>: "He was courageous, and he had enough heart to challenge wrong," Gregory Sain, a community supporter, said of Jackson’s impact. "We have to continue to motivate, inspire and raise up other individuals. Rev. Jackson will be a hero to many people."</p><p><b>More on Rev. Jackson</b>: </p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" style="line-height: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px; margin-left: 24px; padding: 0px; list-style-type: disc;" id="rte-e9b7c156-0cd4-11f1-bea8-e9eccad1f06e"><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-x/" target="_blank" >10 facts about the Rev. Jackson and his connection to Chicago you might not know</a></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-c/" target="_blank" >Timeline of Rev. Jackson’s decades of civil rights activism, political efforts</a></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-q/" target="_blank" >Rev. Jesse Jackson and Chicago mayors — a tense, fraught relationship</a></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-a/" target="_blank" >Lights, camera, Jackson: Civil Rights leader also became a pop culture presence</a></li></ul><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-f/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4> WATCH: REFLECTIONS ON REV. The River West company designed and built architectural models for developers and architects that provided an advance look — often with astonishing accuracy and detail — of the buildings, neighborhoods, skyscrapers and places planned for the city. That all came to an end this month when the company shut its doors for good.</p><p><b>End of an era</b>: Columbian Model President Catherine Tinker decided at the beginning of the year to retire. She said her partners didn’t want to continue the company, fearful that technological advancements in creating virtual models would ultimately eat away their business. "They are concerned that because of the digital revolution, there’s not enough work — or physical models anymore," she said.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: In the city of "no little plans," physical architectural models were once a big thing. Over the decades, they were our first look at many well-known projects around town: Crown Hall at the Illinois Institute of Technology, Marina City, Sears Tower, Central Station, the Harold Washington Library entries, Millennium Park and more.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-w/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>MORE NEWS YOU NEED about the Illinois Republican primary race for governor</a></h3><p></p><h5>Reporting by <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-ji/" target="_blank" >Mitchell Armentrout</a></h5><p><b>Who's running</b>: Darren Bailey, Ted Dabrowski, Rick Heidner and James Mendrick are running for the Republican nomination for governor to advance to a general election matchup with Gov. JB Pritzker, who is unopposed in the Democratic primary.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: The Republican nominee will aim to prevent a third term for Pritzker, who is widely considered to have presidential ambitions in 2028. Republicans have been shut out of all statewide offices in Illinois since Pritzker unseated former Gov. Bruce Rauner in 2018.</p><p><b>Their backstories</b>: They are a farmer and ex-state legislator, a former leader of a conservative website and the Illinois Policy Institute, a video gambling mogul and real estate entrepreneur, and a two-term DuPage County sheriff.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-jd/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>FROM THE PRESS BOX ⚾🏀🏈</h4><ul class="rte2-style-ul" style="line-height: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px; margin-left: 24px; padding: 0px; list-style-type: disc;" id="rte-e9b884a0-0cd4-11f1-bea8-e9eccad1f06e"><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-jh/" target="_blank" ><b>Union boss resigns</b></a>: MLB Players Association boss Tony Clark abruptly stepped down this week — bad timing, as the collective bargaining agreement expires this year, Cubs players said Tuesday. class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Oak Park Area Arts Council members Taz Stahlnecker, Camille Wilson and Jaime Garza.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Tyler Pasciak LaRiviere/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-tt/" target="_blank" >Hundreds of murals grace Oak Park’s Green Line embankment — and more arrive yearly</a></h3><p></p><h5>Reporting by <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-ti/" target="_blank" >Genevieve Bookwalter</a></h5><p>Colorful images of turtles, monsters, parrots, people and more cover the walls supporting the Green Line as it goes through the heart of Oak Park. About 230 are on both sides of the embankment.</p><p>Since 2010, the Oak Park Area Arts Council has worked with village officials to commission 20 to 30 murals a year to be painted in the frames of concrete.</p><p>They are found on aptly named North Boulevard and South Boulevard — on the north and south sides of the L tracks — from downtown Oak Park to the CTA Green Line Austin station.</p><p>"There’s still a lot more to do," says Camille Wilson White, executive director of the Oak Park Area Arts Council. "We are proud of these murals. People love them."</p><p>Wilson White said the collection contains murals by dozens of artists who come from Oak Park, the greater Chicago area and across the U.S.</p><p>Communities around the country want to learn how they can start their own mural walls, Wilson White said. "It’s a cool thing about being in Oak Park. It’s the art of uncommon community."</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-td/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>YOUR DAILY QUESTION ☕️</h4><p>Yesterday, we asked you: <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-tk/" target="_blank" ><b>What is your defining memory of Rev. Jesse Jackson?</b></a></p><p>Here’s some of what you said…</p><p>"As a Northwestern University undergraduate, I marched with Jesse Jackson in the streets of Chicago for civil rights. In 1968, we were tear-gassed by Richard J. Daley's cops — illegally. I also marched with him in anti-Vietnam War marches." — <i>Harvey J. Graff</i></p><p>"My husband and his friends frequented the Division Street Baths in the '70s thru the '90s. It was always a special occasion when 'The Reverend' and his entourage came into the steam room. Mr Jackson, like any good politician, would shake hands and introduce himself to everyone sitting on the tiled tiers. His charisma was contagious." — <i>Sandy Doyle</i></p><p>"My special memory of Jesse Jackson happened Super Tuesday — Feb. 5, 2008. I was an Obama volunteer attending the party and broadcast of Barack Obama's speech at the Hyatt. Jesse Jackson was in the bleachers behind me doing live shots with reporters. After the cameras were locked on Barack, I noticed Jesse alone and holding an Obama sign. His mind and heart were elsewhere — perhaps pondering what 'could have been' for himself or one of his children. It was the tenderest moment of a politician, activist, human that I've seen up close and personal." — <i>Doreen Rice</i></p><p>"I had the honor to know and do some work with him, appearing on his radio show, receiving the Martin Luther King Jr. and Lyndon Johnson award from him, and assisting his organizations where I could. I have spent most of my life defending people facing the death penalty, work which Rev. Jackson supported. My memory is not just [his] amazing work ... It's of him sitting quietly with me at a table at the Illinois Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers dinner honoring his son, former Congressman Jackson. It's of him taking the time to speak with my then-teenage son, of his kind inquiries regarding my late husband's health, and his concern for humanity in general." — <i>Andrea Lyon</i></p><p><b>Have your own memories of Rev. Jackson? </b><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-tu/" target="_blank" ><b>Share them here</b></a><b>.</b></p><hr><p>Thanks for reading the Sun-Times Morning Edition!<br>Got a story you think we missed? <a class="Link" href="mailto:newsletters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >Email us here.</a></p><hr><p><b>Written and curated by</b>: Matt Moore<br><b>Editor</b>: Eydie Cubarrubia</p><hr><p><i>The Chicago Sun-Times is a nonprofit supported by readers like you. Become a member to make stories like these free and available to everyone. Learn more at </i><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrlkly-l-il/" target="_blank" ><i>suntimes.com/member</i></a><i>.</i></p>

entries.title: City workers find body of woman gunned down on dirt road on Far South Side
entries.summary: <p>City garbage workers Tuesday afternoon found the body of a woman lying on the side of a dirt road who had been fatally shot in the Altgeld Gardens neighborhood.</p><p>It was about 12:15 p.m. as the truck traveled its regular route in the 600 block of East 134th Place when workers spotted her, lying "on the side of the dirt road in a prone position with multiple shell casings around her and multiple gunshot wounds to the victim's body," a police report said. </p><p>According to the report, two witnesses reported hearing gunshots about 9 p.m. Monday night. </p><p>Paramedics from the Chicago fire department went to the scene and the unidentified woman, who appeared to be in her 20s or 30s, was pronounced dead, the report said.</p><p>Area 2 detectives are investigating. </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Deadly shooting reported in Bronzeville neighborhood
entries.summary: <p>Police were searching for an assailant who fatally gunned down a person Tuesday night in the Bronzeville neighborhood on the South Side. </p><p>The person, an unidentified male, was found on the street with multiple gunshot wounds around 10:15 p.m. in the 700 block of East 37th Street, Chicago police said. </p><p>He was taken to the University of Chicago Medical Center where he was pronounced dead, police said. </p><p>Area 1 detectives were investigating. </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Gov. JB Pritzker's $56B state budget proposal includes new taxes on social media companies, casinos
entries.summary: <p>SPRINGFIELD — Gov. JB Pritzker wants to implement a new tax on major social media companies like Facebook, X and TikTok to help balance a $56 billion state budget, as part of a state spending plan that also counts on additional tax revenue from casinos and large corporations, according to details released Wednesday.</p><p>The governor’s latest budget proposal, the eighth of his tenure, doesn’t rock the boat much otherwise as Pritzker and Democrats who control the Illinois General Assembly emphasize cost-of-living concerns in a midterm election year.</p><p>Declaring it “a moment to stand up for Illinois and be loud for America,” Pritzker delivered his proposal with his annual State of the State address at the Capitol, a speech that officials said would outline an “affordability agenda” to help bring down costs for residents in terms of health care, housing, education and energy.</p><p>As the governor mulls a 2028 presidential run, he’s expected to highlight how Trump administration policies are raising such prices. </p><p>In his address, Pritzker was expected to outline his spring legislative agenda, which will include a push to cut red tape on local zoning laws to allow for more duplexes, granny flats and other housing. He was also set to advocate for a ban on cellphones for students in schools, along with a crackdown on junk fees on many online purchases.</p><p>Pritzker’s budget team pointed to persistent threats of funding cuts under President Donald Trump’s administration as the impetus for what largely amounts to a maintenance budget at about $56 billion in spending, up about $878 million from the current budget year and landing at a projected surplus of $24 million.</p><p>"Unlike the federal government, every year Illinois must balance its budget," Pritzker was set to say in prepared remarks. "When Donald Trump is taking resources away that are rightfully ours, none of us — Democrats or Republicans — should be OK with that. So as we embark on this journey of maintaining our state’s now re-established record of fiscal responsibility, I want to say to anyone on either side of the aisle: if you want to talk about our FY2027 budget, you must first demand the return of the money and resources this president has taken from the people of Illinois."</p><p>The governor’s office had projected a $2.2 billion budget shortfall in October, now estimating $399 million in lost revenue next year due to congressional Republicans’ funding cuts for many social services and other federal programs, and the state assuming about $100 million in new administrative costs for food assistance and Medicaid programs. Meanwhile, the state is fighting in court to retain about $1 billion in various federal grants.</p><p>Pritzker’s office is counting on about $4.1 billion in federal funds in the upcoming year as credit analysts predict a rocky year for the Illinois economy.</p><p>To help make ends meet, some $200 million would be banked from big social media companies that Pritzker wants to tax, based on the number of users they have in the state.</p><p>It’s similar to the tax Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson proposed in his city budget proposal last fall, a controversial measure that was retained in the alternate spending plan ultimately approved City Council members. Tech companies have vowed <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/city-hall/2025/10/21/brandon-johnson-social-media-tax-chicago-budget" target="_blank" ><u>to challenge such a measure in court</u></a>.</p><p>Chiding tech companies that “profit off of surveilling youth, creating addictive algorithms, and abandoning their responsibility to keep kids and consumers safe,” Pritzker’s plan would charge social media companies a monthly fee based on the number of users in Illinois they have beyond 100,000. That would be at rates of $0.10 per user up to 500,000 users; $40,000 plus $0.25 per user up to a million; and $165,000 plus $0.50 per user over a million. It would prohibit companies from passing those costs onto users.</p><p>The governor’s proposal also counts on $269 million in additional corporate income tax revenue by adjusting how much big companies can deduct as losses over several years.</p><p>Pritzker’s plan also would generate about $120 million by taxing table games at casinos at the same rate as slot machines, which are currently at a higher bracket. That’s the governor’s only proposed change to gambling taxation in the state after two years of major additional levies on the state’s massive sports betting industry.</p><p>It doesn’t include any of the progressive revenue ideas that had been pushed by the General Assembly’s left flank, including taxing digital ads and gains on billionaires’ assets, hiking taxes on offshore earnings and closing corporate tax loopholes.</p><p>Nor did Pritzker’s budget team mention <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/springfield/2026/01/20/bears-stadium-northwest-indiana-arlington-heights-ballys-chicago-casino-general-assembly-spring-agenda" target="_blank" ><u>a possible surcharge tax on millionaires</u></a>, an idea that has been floated by Illinois House Speaker Emanuel “Chris” Welch that would require a state constitutional amendment. A similar Pritzker-backed initiative failed in 2020.</p><p>The governor’s spending plan includes $305 million for schools under the state’s evidence-based funding formula, a figure short of the usual $350 million because the remainder was used as part of a property tax relief program last year.</p><p>It also makes the state’s required $10.7 billion payment toward pension systems that are collectively facing more than $140 billion in unfunded liabilities. Pritzker is expected to renew his push to extend the state’s goal of 100% funding by 2048, instead of the current state law with a goal of reaching 90% funded by 2045.</p><p>Additionally, Pritzker’s spending proposal sets aside a flat $721.4 million for Monetary Award Program grants in financial aid for college students, while increasing public university and community college funding by 1%. The Department of Children and Family Services would see a $74 million budget increase to $1.7 billion. It also includes about $250 million for housing programs.</p><p>Pritzker’s budget proposal sets the stage for three months of negotiations in Springfield. Lawmakers have to approve a spending plan by the end of May, for the fiscal year that starts July 1.</p>
entries.author: Matt Trunfio

entries.title: Detienen a delincuente sexual registrado acusado de violar a una mujer en callejón de Humboldt Park
entries.summary: <p>Un hombre sospechoso de haber violado a una mujer en un callejón del vecindario de Humboldt Park en enero fue detenido.</p><p>Arthur White, un delincuente sexual registrado de 40 años, enfrenta un cargo de delito grave por agresión sexual criminal agravada. Según los fiscales, supuestamente siguió a una mujer por Lawndale Avenue el 12 de enero y le preguntó si necesitaba su ayuda.</p><p>Cuando ella rechazó su oferta, White caminó delante de la mujer, luego se metió en un viaducto. Cuando ella pasó el viaducto, según la policía, la agarró y la empujó hacia un callejón en la cuadra 1400 al norte de Lawndale Avenue. La mujer gritó pidiendo ayuda mientras él la empujaba contra los botes de basura y se quitaba el cinturón, dijeron los fiscales.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-c80000" name="module-c80000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>La mujer intentó escapar, pero White la sostuvo y le dio un golpe en la cabeza, indicaron los fiscales. La arrastró por su suéter y le bajó los pantalones. Luego se bajó sus pantalones y la violó.</p><p>La mujer gritó, pero White le cubrió la boca mientras ella luchaba por respirar, dijeron los fiscales. White abandonó la escena después de la supuesta agresión.</p><p>La mujer llamó al 911 y fue llevada al Hospital Mount Sinai, donde recibió atención y el personal del hospital recolectó evidencia para un kit de violación. La policía habló con dueños de negocios cercanos a la escena y obtuvo un video de vigilancia que corroboró el relato de la mujer.</p><p>Una semana después de la supuesta agresión, los fiscales dicen que White se acercó a una mujer en un restaurante Subway cercano y la acosó. Cuando ella no respondió, él le tocó los glúteos y ella sacó una navaja y le dijo que no la volviera a tocar.</p><p>White fue arrestado, y la mujer en el caso de agresión sexual lo identificó como el hombre que la violó, dijeron los fiscales.</p><p>White es un delincuente sexual registrado que violó a su hermana de 5 años cuando tenía 15.</p><p>En una audiencia judicial esta semana, se ordenó la detención de White hasta su próxima fecha en corte el 24 de febrero.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Mary Norkol

entries.title: Illinois reporta el primer caso de sarampión de 2026
entries.summary: <p>El primer caso de sarampión del año en Illinois ha sido detectado en la parte sur del estado, dijeron funcionarios de salud estatales el martes.</p><p>Las personas que asistieron a los servicios en la Iglesia Luterana Good Shepherd en Collinsville, Illinois, a 15 millas al este de St. Louis, el 8 de febrero entre las 8 a.m. y las 12:15 p.m. estuvieron potencialmente expuestas al virus.</p><p>La agencia de salud del estado enfatizó que la mejor protección contra el sarampión es la vacuna MMR de dos dosis, que protege contra el sarampión, las paperas y la rubéola.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-390000" name="module-390000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>La primera dosis se administra cuando un niño tiene entre 12 y 15 meses, proporcionando un 93% de inmunidad, y la segunda dosis se aplica entre los 4 y 7 años, aumentando la inmunidad al 97%.</p><p>“Este primer caso reportado de sarampión en Illinois en 2026 es un recordatorio para nuestros residentes de Illinois de que esta enfermedad se puede prevenir con la vacunación al día”, dijo el Dr. Sameer Vohra, Director del Departamento de Salud Pública de Illinois (IDPH).</p><p>“Con casi mil casos en los Estados Unidos en lo que va de este año, el equipo del IDPH ha estado preparándose, trabajando en estrecha colaboración con los socios locales de salud pública y atención médica en estrategias para reducir la propagación y minimizar los brotes... Le recomiendo a nuestros residentes de Illinois que se aseguren de que ellos y sus familiares estén al día con la vacuna MMR y todas las demás inmunizaciones apropiadas para su edad”, agregó.</p><p>Los síntomas pueden tardar de una a tres semanas en aparecer después de la exposición a alguien con sarampión, según los funcionarios de salud, lo que hace que sea aún más probable que se propague, ya que el sarampión también es una enfermedad altamente contagiosa, según la agencia de salud.</p><p>Una persona puede infectar hasta 18 individuos. En contraste, la tasa de infección de la gripe es de aproximadamente una a dos personas.</p><p>Debido a esto, cualquier persona que no esté vacunada pero que esté expuesta debe monitorearse para detectar síntomas como erupción, fiebre alta, tos, secreción nasal y ojos rojos y llorosos durante 21 días, dijo la agencia de salud del estado.</p><p>El primer caso de sarampión de este año llega mucho antes que <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/health/2025/04/24/idph-reports-first-measles-case-this-year-in-southern-illinois" target="_blank" >el primer caso del año pasado</a>, que no se detectó hasta mediados de abril.</p><p>Illinois registró 14 casos en 2025 <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/health/2025/07/11/illinois-measles-outbreak-over-state-health-department-officials" target="_blank" >durante su pico</a> —cuando casi 1,300 casos surgieron a nivel nacional en un corto periodo, el peor brote en más de 30 años— una fuerte caída comparado al <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/health/2024/05/30/chicago-measles-outbreak-declared-over-health-department" target="_blank" >brote de sarampión que duró tres meses en Chicago</a> de 2024, donde se confirmaron 64 casos.</p><p>Para obtener más información sobre el sarampión, comunícate con tu proveedor de atención médica o visita la <a class="Link" href="https://dph.illinois.gov/topics-services/diseases-and-conditions/measles.html" target="_blank" >página web del Departamento de Salud Pública de Illinois sobre el sarampión</a> o el <a class="Link" href="https://www.cdc.gov/measles/index.html" target="_blank" >sitio del Centros para el Control y Prevención de Enfermedades (CDC) sobre el sarampión</a>.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Ash Wednesday observers look to strengthen relationship with God during Lent
entries.summary: <p>Ash Wednesday observers throughout the Chicago area attended Mass and had their foreheads marked with ashes in the shape of a cross to mark the beginning of Lent. </p><p>Messages of unity and acknowledging one's own mortality were echoed during Mass at the Holy Name Cathedral as Rev. Louis Cameli called for congregates to embrace repentance.</p><p>"These ashes represent an embrace of repentance, conversion, a change of heart, re-calibrating our lives so that they can be more in conformity with what God wants," Cameli preached.</p><p>Ash Wednesday marks the beginning of Lent, the 40-day period of reflection, praying, fasting and donating to the needy, according to the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops.</p><p>Catholics between 18 and 59 years old are typically required to fast. When fasting, a person can eat one full meal as well as two smaller meals that don’t make up a full meal. It is also tradition to abstain from eating meat on Fridays during Lent — and on Ash Wednesday.</p><p>Bridget O'Brien, director of ministry at Old St. Patrick's Catholic Church, noted the fasting is to "make us conscious of our hunger for God." </p><p>"It helps me to reflect on the fact that one day I will die and reflect on the life I want to lead," O'Brien said. </p><p>Tom Dowling, a 59-year-old River North resident who has gone to Holy Name Cathedral for about four years, is hoping to become "more steadfast in prayer."</p><p>"I want to give up some of the things in my life I'm attached to [and make sure] that I'm attached to God," Dowling said.</p><p>Ash Wednesday observers pick something enjoyable — typically a favorite food or pleasurable vice — to sacrifice for the 40-day period.</p><p>Janett Diaz, hopes to use Lent as an opportunity to give up earthly things. Diaz, who is visiting Chicago from Panama, made it a priority to attend Ash Wednesday Mass while abroad.</p><p>"For me, it's less shopping and maybe a little less screen time and a little less pride," Diaz said.</p><p>Like Diaz, Albany Park resident Ana Pizzaro wants to be closer to God and plans to use Lent as a motivational tool to establish better religious discipline.</p><p>"I came from ash, and one day when I die I will become ash again. So we need to remember that God is who made us and we will once we live our lives, we will return to Him," Pizzaro, 49, said. "I like to come to Mass everyday but I need to find a way to come on time. And of course I will pray more."</p><p>Observers urged anyone interested in learning more about Ash Wednesday to visit their local church in-person and be part of the community.</p><p>"Even if you start by sitting in the last row and at least listen to what's going on in the church [and] in Mass, that helps you start," Pizzaro said. "That would be a good step in starting to look for God."</p><p>O'Brien was "very moved" by the levels of diversity she has seen in congregants at the church. </p><p>"You've got guys with mud on their boots and hard hats who are coming together right off of a construction site, you've got nurses in scrubs, people in very fancy suits ... just a reminder of the brotherhood and sisterhood and everyone coming together because this is a meaningful start to them," O'Brien said. </p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item"> <bsp-carousel class="Carousel Enhancement" entries.author: Mohammad Samra

entries.title: Every known federal prosecution in Chicago tied to Trump’s immigration blitz
entries.summary: <p>Federal prosecutors in Chicago have accused 32 known defendants of nonimmigration crimes tied to Operation Midway Blitz. Many were accused of assaulting or resisting federal agents or officers.</p><p>Seventeen of those defendants have already been cleared. Grand jurors refused to indict at least three of the 17, and another member of that group was found not guilty at trial.</p><p>Meanwhile, prosecutors have entered into a deferred-prosecution agreement with one additional defendant. If that person abides by certain terms over a set period of time, the feds have agreed to drop the charges in that case as well.</p><p>The Chicago Sun-Times is tracking all of the known criminal cases tied to Operation Midway Blitz:</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-6e0000" name="html-embed-module-6e0000"></a><div
