data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="JACKSONFAMILY_260219-049.jpg" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b3a8e6a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F59%2Ffd%2Fc7e971c445d68cb67f85adde2f21%2Fjacksonfamily-260219-049.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1db85b8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F59%2Ffd%2Fc7e971c445d68cb67f85adde2f21%2Fjacksonfamily-260219-049.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b3a8e6a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F59%2Ffd%2Fc7e971c445d68cb67f85adde2f21%2Fjacksonfamily-260219-049.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Flanked by her siblings, Santita Jackson speaks about her late father, Rev. Jesse Jackson Sr., outside her family home Wednesday in South Shore.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2026/02/17/rev-jesse-jackson-civil-rights-leader-rainbow-push-obituary" >Rev. Jesse Jackson, civil rights leader and Chicago icon, dead at 84</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>Spencer Leak, Jr., a close friend of the family, said when he got the call about the reverend’s passing, he hopped in his car at 1:42 a.m. and went to be with the Jacksons. He said Jacqueline Jackson, now 81, held him and said, “Boy, you better squeeze me tight because if it wasn’t for your grandfather, we don’t know where we would be.”</p><p>It was Leak’s grandfather, A.R. Leak, an established businessman and owner of what is now Leak & Sons Funeral Homes, who provided an apartment for the young Jacksons to live in as they got their footing in their new town.</p><p>“[The Leaks] said, ‘We've got a nice building, and we live in it,’ ” Santita Jackson said. “They helped [my parents] to establish a line of credit so they could buy furniture, and they carpeted the apartment so the children could roll around and play all we wanted.”</p><p>The families would stay close friends and neighbors in South Shore for years to come, with their children becoming like brothers and sisters.</p><p>Spencer Leak Jr., now 56, recalled playing basketball with the Jackson boys in the driveway and having dinner with the family.</p><p>“No politics [were] brought up; it was just all laughing and joking like a family,” Leak said. “The public knows Reverend Jackson as this civil rights leader. I know him as a father [figure] and a brother to my dad.”</p><p>Leak also recalled slapping “Run Jesse Run” stickers on cars during the reverend’s historic campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination in 1984.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-c70000" name="image-c70000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/cc8f019/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1371x769+0+97/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F10%2Fde98a2004f5e896876afeebc5c9d%2F11-28-00-hein-evans-6.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ada5a84/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1371x769+0+97/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F10%2Fde98a2004f5e896876afeebc5c9d%2F11-28-00-hein-evans-6.JPG 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ba853ae/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1371x769+0+97/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F10%2Fde98a2004f5e896876afeebc5c9d%2F11-28-00-hein-evans-6.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Rev. Clay Evans and Rev Jesse Jackson." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ba853ae/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1371x769+0+97/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F10%2Fde98a2004f5e896876afeebc5c9d%2F11-28-00-hein-evans-6.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b1a453d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1371x769+0+97/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F10%2Fde98a2004f5e896876afeebc5c9d%2F11-28-00-hein-evans-6.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ba853ae/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1371x769+0+97/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F10%2Fde98a2004f5e896876afeebc5c9d%2F11-28-00-hein-evans-6.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Rev. Clay Evans, pastor and founder of Fellowship Baptist Church, was a close friend of Jackson.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Rich Hein/Sun-Times file</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><b>Spiritual mentorship</b></h3><p></p><p>But long before Jesse Jackson ascended to the national stage, he struggled to provide for his growing family in his early Chicago days.</p><p>Santita Jackson recalled the time in the mid-1960s when her dad, by then a father of three who had run out of scholarship money from the Chicago Theological Seminary, was waiting in line at a food pantry at Fellowship Missionary Baptist Church, where he was serving as a youth minister.</p><p>Santita Jackson said the legendary civil rights leader Rev. Clay Evans, founder of Fellowship church, pulled her father over and said “I’m not gonna let you stand in this line.” After that day, Evans and the church made sure the family had groceries each week, and that the young parents had the best babysitters the congregation could offer.</p><p>Another pastor, Rev. James Bevel, vouched for Jesse Jackson to lead Martin Luther King Jr.’s Operation Breadbasket — which would quickly elevate Jackson in the civil rights movement and lay the foundation for what later became Rainbow PUSH.</p><p>Rev. Martin Deppe, a United Methodist Church pastor who worked on Operation Breadbasket, would also remain a close friend of Jackson’s. He recounted to WBEZ about the first time he saw the captivating leader.</p><p>“He came in, and like wildfire, within two or three weeks, he was running the meeting,” Deppe said. “His charisma [and] strengths were so, so evident that the leading Black pastors yielded the gavel to him.”</p><p>Deppe said Chicago’s pastors embraced the magnetic Jackson, mentoring him and connecting him to other powerful businessmen and city leaders — especially as Operation Breadbasket began attracting thousands of members.</p><p>“[Jackson] didn’t start out in politics, he started out in the church,” said Deppe, author of “Operation Breadbasket: An Untold Story of Civil Rights in Chicago, 1966-1971.”</p><p>As Jackson’s star rose in the 1970s and 80s, Chicago’s pastoral community provided spiritual guidance. Evans, who had pulled Jackson out of the bread line decades earlier, would remain a mentor and close confidante, according to Rev. James Meeks.</p><p>“Reverend Clay Evans was the pastor of this family until his death” in 2019, Meeks said.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-aa0000" name="image-aa0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/efdd0d0/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7699x4321+0+407/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F70%2F76%2Fd68d941243558f2e81d2acb67719%2Fimg-9339.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/432af8b/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7699x4321+0+407/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F70%2F76%2Fd68d941243558f2e81d2acb67719%2Fimg-9339.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/13426cb/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7699x4321+0+407/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F70%2F76%2Fd68d941243558f2e81d2acb67719%2Fimg-9339.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Martin L. Deppe is a founding member of Operation Breadbasket." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/13426cb/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7699x4321+0+407/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F70%2F76%2Fd68d941243558f2e81d2acb67719%2Fimg-9339.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8e072db/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7699x4321+0+407/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F70%2F76%2Fd68d941243558f2e81d2acb67719%2Fimg-9339.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/13426cb/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7699x4321+0+407/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F70%2F76%2Fd68d941243558f2e81d2acb67719%2Fimg-9339.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Rev. Martin L. Deppe was a founding member of Operation Breadbasket and a close friend of Rev. Jesse Jackson.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Manuel Martinez/WBEZ</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3>Finding community in South Shore</h3><p>In addition to the spiritual and material support Jackson received, his children, too, would flourish and find their own way in the City of Big Shoulders.</p><p>Yusef Jackson, the reverend’s youngest son who is now chief operating officer at Rainbow PUSH, said the South Shore neighborhood played a crucial role in his family’s life.</p><p>“What made the South Shore community so special was they allowed us to be normal children in public school, playing in the park,” he told WBEZ. “Each Jackson lives in South Shore [today]. That’s how important the community is to us.”</p><p>Santita Jackson said she “couldn’t ask for more” from her hometown. “It sent two of my brothers [Jesse Jr. and Jonathan] to Congress, it’s given me a wonderful career in radio,” she said.</p><p>When asked whether her father ever considered moving to another city, she scoffed, adding that Chicago was the only place her father could do the work he did.</p><p>“It is a town that is full of strivers, of people who really came here to grow: Blacks who had been chased out of the South, refugees and immigrants looking for opportunities,” she continued, remembering the young couple that drove through downtown Chicago on that day in 1964.</p><p>She added: “Go elsewhere for what? There is no place like Chicago, and it is our home.”</p><p><i>Contributing: Somer Van Benton</i><br></p>
entries.author: Nicole Jeanine Johnson

entries.title: Man's death at Naval Station Great Lakes is under investigation
entries.summary: <p>The death of a Florida man at Naval Station Great Lakes is under investigation after he was found unresponsive in the barracks Sunday, according to the Lake County coroner’s office.</p><p>Navy Region Mid-Atlantic Fire and Emergency Services and the Great Lakes Police Department responded about 12:15 p.m. to a medical call in the barracks of the base and found Joshua Jones, 19, unresponsive, the office said in a statement. He was pronounced dead at the scene.</p><p>Coroner's officials confirmed Jones was stationed at the base. Naval Station Great Lakes didn't immediately respond to a request for comment.</p><p>An autopsy was conducted, a cause or manner of death has not yet been released. The Lake County coroner's office said autopsy results were pending the completion of an expanded toxicology test.</p><p>The Naval Criminal Investigative Service is investigating.</p><p>Kelsey Danner, spokesperson for the Surface Combat Systems Training Command Great Lakes, on Wednesday confirmed Jones was a Seaman Apprentice and said grief counseling services were available through Surface Combat Systems Training Command Great Lakes and the chaplain.</p><p>"The Navy mourns the loss of our shipmate and sends condolences to the Sailor’s family, friends, and fellow Sailors during this difficult time," Danner said.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-270000" name="image-270000"></a> entries.title: Blackhawks debut adjusted defensive system in first practice after Olympic break
entries.summary: <p><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks" target="_blank" >Blackhawks</a> coach Jeff Blashill's hints of a system adjustment coming out of the Olympic break came to fruition Wednesday.</p><p>The Hawks spent the second half of their first of six official practices before the regular season resumes Feb. 26 working on an altered defensive-zone system.</p><p>Blashill took inspiration from his penalty-killing system, which has worked brilliantly. It torments opponents with its high-pressure approach and leads the NHL with an 85.7% kill rate. And that's with just four men on the ice, so why not do the same with five during even-strength play?</p><p>"I’ve said it lots of times: we have really good killers. But those same guys are on the ice five-on-five," Blashill said Wednesday. "If you can dictate where the puck’s going, you have a better chance of [dialing up] pressure. If you can’t dictate where the puck’s going, you can’t pressure it. </p><p>"On our penalty kill, we’ve done a good job of dictating and reading those pressure points. We’ve [also] done a good job on the penalty kill of knowing when to reset and protect the middle. Those two things are going to be important for us in the 'D'-zone [system], as well."</p><p>This season, the Hawks are using a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2025/09/27/blackhawks-jeff-blashill-defensive-systems-penalty-kill-nhl-hockey-strategy" target="_blank" >hybrid defensive-zone system</a>: zone defense down low, man-on-man defense elsewhere. The past couple years, they played entirely zone defense. That man-on-man element means, for example, their defensemen sometimes have to follow opposing forwards all the way up toward the blue line.</p><p>The biggest change Wednesday is that their strong-side wingers will now be more aggressive pressuring the puck along the boards.</p><p>Previously, the Hawks' strong-side defenseman would pressure the puck, and the winger would hang back and read off of the defenseman. Now, the strong-side winger will pressure the puck-carrier no matter what, and if the defenseman reads that the winger has him properly covered, he can drop back to guard or box out around the crease.</p><p>"[The winger] doesn't need to make a read anymore: 'Does this guy have space? Is my 'D'-man going downhill, or is he going to the inside?'" forward Jason Dickinson said. "[Those were] different reads he had to make in those situations. Now it's just pressure. You create the pressure; then everybody else will react off of that. That's the biggest change."</p><p>This adjustment will force Hawks' centers to make more reads and think harder when they come out of the corners, and it also necessitates more coverage handoffs that could momentarily leave opposing players open.</p><p>But it should generally reduce the workload placed upon the Hawks' defensive corps — an extremely young unit that sagged under that heavy weight in January.</p><p>"Our 'D'-men won't have to climb high as often," Dickinson added. "It'll still happen where we'll be like, 'Hey, you <i>have </i>to go with this guy.' But more often than not, they should be able to retreat back to the net because our winger will be striking that guy, and then our center will be able to come out from underneath."</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">I’m back in Chicago for the Blackhawks’ first official practice back in action: <a href="https://t.co/YI4hDj6z64">pic.twitter.com/YI4hDj6z64</a></p>— Ben Pope (@BenPopeCST) <a href="https://twitter.com/BenPopeCST/status/2024167029985456324?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 18, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p>The Hawks had their AHL affiliate in Rockford test out this altered system during back-to-back games last weekend, producing video clips for the Hawks to review and analyze this week. Blashill has tried to keep his and Rockford coach Jared Nightingale's systems in sync as much as possible.</p><p>Then the Hawks called up Sam Rinzel and Kevin Korchinski from Rockford, giving them seven healthy defensemen even with Wyatt Kaiser expected to miss time due to a lower-body injury suffered in the final game before the Olympic break.</p><p>Enigmatic rookie Artyom Levshunov's individual development program continues, and he skated as the seventh defenseman in practice Wednesday. But Blashill said the lineup for next Thursday at the Predators won't be determined for a while yet.</p><h3><b>Notes</b></h3><p>• The Hawks will have only 41 home games again next season — despite the regular season extending to 84 games — because they've been selected for an undisclosed NHL "special event." That suggests a Europe trip, which would be the Hawks' first since they visited Berlin and Prague in 2019.</p><p>For the 41 home games, season-ticket prices will rise by a modest average of 2%.</p><p>• Connor Bedard has resumed taking his own faceoffs, allowing Frank Nazar to move back to his own line. On Wednesday, Bedard centered Ryan Greene and Andre Burakovsky, and Nazar centered Oliver Moore and Tyler Bertuzzi.</p><p>• Kaiser and Teuvo Teravainen, who advanced to the Olympic semifinals with Finland, were the only players absent from practice.</p><p>• Prospect goalie Stan Berezhnoy, who has made 15 appearances for Rockford this season, has been suspended for 20 games by the AHL for testing positive for a prohibited substance (Rockford has 23 games left in their season). General manager Kyle Davidson said in a statement the Hawks were informed last week.</p><p>"While Stanislav did not knowingly take a prohibited substance, we believe his positive test is a result of a supplement he was consuming at the time," Davidson said. "Stanislav has taken full responsibility for the situation, and the organization praises him for the maturity and accountability he has shown."</p><p></p><bsp-list-loadmore class="PageListH" entries.title: Católicos de Chicago buscan fortalecer su fe el Miércoles de Ceniza
entries.summary: <p>Los observadores del Miércoles de Ceniza en toda el área de Chicago asistieron a misa y tuvieron sus frentes marcadas con cenizas en forma de cruz para marcar el comienzo de la Cuaresma.</p><p>Durante la Misa en la Catedral del Santo Nombre, se escucharon mensajes de unidad y el reconocimiento de la propia mortalidad, mientras el Rev. Louis Cameli instaba a los congregantes a abrazar el arrepentimiento.</p><p>“Estas cenizas representan un abrazo al arrepentimiento, a la conversión, un cambio de corazón, recalibrar nuestras vidas para que puedan estar más en conformidad con lo que Dios quiere”, predicó Cameli.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-ae0000" name="module-ae0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>El Miércoles de Ceniza marca el inicio de la Cuaresma, un periodo de 40 días de reflexión, oración, ayuno y donación a los necesitados, según la Conferencia de Obispos Católicos de los Estados Unidos.</p><p>Generalmente, se requiere que los católicos de entre 18 y 59 años ayunen. Durante el ayuno, una persona puede comer una comida completa, así como dos comidas más pequeñas. También es tradición abstenerse de comer carne los viernes durante la Cuaresma —y en el Miércoles de Ceniza.</p><p>Bridget O'Brien, directora de ministerio en la Iglesia Católica de Old St. Patrick, destacó que el ayuno es para “hacernos conscientes de nuestra hambre de Dios”.</p><p>“Me ayuda a reflexionar sobre el hecho de que un día moriré y reflexionar sobre la vida que quiero llevar”, dijo O'Brien.</p><p>Tom Dowling, un residente de River North de 59 años que ha asistido a la Catedral del Santo Nombre durante aproximadamente cuatro años, espera hacerse “más firme en la oración”.</p><p>“Quiero renunciar a algunas cosas de mi vida a las que estoy apegado [y asegurarme] de que estoy aferrado a Dios”, dijo Dowling.</p><p>Los observadores del Miércoles de Ceniza eligen algo placentero —generalmente una comida favorita o algún vicio placentero— para sacrificar durante el periodo de 40 días.</p><p>Janett Diaz espera utilizar la Cuaresma como una oportunidad para renunciar a cosas terrenales. Diaz, quien está de visita en Chicago desde Panamá, hizo de su prioridad asistir a la Misa del Miércoles de Ceniza mientras estaba en el extranjero.</p><p>“Para mí, se trata de hacer menos compras y quizás un poco menos de tiempo frente a la pantalla y un poco menos de orgullo”, dijo Diaz.</p><p>Al igual que Diaz, la residente de Albany Park, Ana Pizzaro, desea acercarse más a Dios y planea usar la Cuaresma como una herramienta motivacional para establecer una mejor disciplina religiosa.</p><p>“Vine del polvo, y un día cuando muera, volveré a ser polvo. Así que necesitamos recordar que Dios es quien nos creó y que una vez que vivamos nuestras vidas, regresaremos a Él”, dijo Pizzaro, de 49 años. “Me gusta venir a misa todos los días, pero necesito encontrar una manera de llegar a tiempo. Y, por supuesto, rezaré más”.</p><p>Los observadores instaron a cualquiera interesado en aprender más sobre el Miércoles de Ceniza a visitar su iglesia local en persona y ser parte de la comunidad.</p><p>“Incluso si comienzas sentándote en la última fila y al menos escuchas lo que está sucediendo en la iglesia [y] en la misa, eso te ayuda a empezar”, dijo Pizzaro. “Ese sería un buen paso para empezar a buscar a Dios”.</p><p>O'Brien se sintió “muy conmovida” por los niveles de diversidad que ha visto en los congregantes de la iglesia.</p><p>“Tienes hombres con lodo en sus botas y cascos que vienen de un sitio de construcción, tienes enfermeras en uniforme, personas en trajes muy elegantes... solo un recordatorio de la hermandad y la fraternidad y de que todos se unen porque este es un inicio significativo para ellos”, dijo O'Brien.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item"> <bsp-carousel class="Carousel Enhancement" data-align-center> entries.title: Combinación de temperaturas cálidas y condiciones secas aumenta riesgo de incendios impulsados por el viento
entries.summary: <p>El área de Chicago está bajo una vigilancia de incendios este miércoles debido a un clima inusualmente cálido, baja humedad en el aire y vientos racheados, según el Servicio Nacional de Meteorología (NWS).</p><p>Con temperaturas máximas pronosticadas en los 60 grados y ráfagas de viento que alcanzan hasta 40 millas por hora, el área se encuentra en un estado de mayor peligro de incendios, según el NWS. Las condiciones climáticas, que incluyen baja humedad en el aire y una reciente falta de lluvia y nieve, también pueden llevar a un mayor riesgo de propagación rápida de incendios.</p><p>La vigilancia del clima de incendios estará vigente hasta la noche del miércoles en gran parte del norte de Illinois, incluyendo los condados de Cook, Lake, DeKalb y DuPage.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-c70000" name="module-c70000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>https://x.com/NWSChicago/status/2023866207443513784</p><p>El NWS recomienda no quemar desechos de jardín debido a la posibilidad de que los incendios se propaguen.</p><p>“Está calentándose, estoy seguro de que muchas personas se sentirán tentadas a quemar desechos de jardín”, dijo el meteorólogo del NWS, Kevin Doom. “Quizás deberían evitarlo, pero si lo hacen, sólo mantengan un ojo... puede ser muy fácil que una chispa se suelte y encienda algo más”.</p><p>Los peligros climáticos de incendios son más comunes en otoño y primavera, aunque pueden ocurrir en cualquier época del año, advirtió Doom. También instó a las personas a tener cuidado al desechar materiales en combustión como colillas de cigarrillos.</p><p>Chicago estableció un récord de <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/weather/2026/02/16/chicago-forecast-warm-weather-record-high-temperature-monday" target="_blank" >temperatura</a> máxima el lunes, ya que la ciudad registró un día de 65 grados.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Mary Norkol
